thread.title_full: Bill Shorten unveils Labor’s plans for sharing economy | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: Bill Shorten unveils Labor’s plans for sharing economy | The
text:
Labor says if it forms government it would aim for ‘tailored, light-touch’ rules for the sharing economy and fair taxation policies.
Opposition leader Bill Shorten outlined his plans in a piece for the Huffington Post, following news earlier this month that the likes of Uber and Airbnb had been sending profits offshore and away from Australia.
“There is huge economic and community potential in the emerging peer-to-peer market,” Shorten wrote.
“I want to see Australia embrace it, while ensuring we have the right rules in place to protect workers, consumers and the public good.”
The Coalition is yet to outline its plans but Malcolm Turnbull earlier this year talked up Airbnb and Uber for an “efficient use of unused inventory.”
“The key to our future prosperity is to be faster, leaner, more productive, more innovative and more collaborative,” Mr Turnbull said.
“And above all, to be more agile.”
The sharing economy, also known as collaborative consumption or the peer-to-peer economy, involves a move away from ownership towards people renting out or sharing things they aren’t using.
Chris Noone, CEO of ASX-listed peer-to-peer marketplace firm Collaborate Corp, said it was “extremely positive” that the opposition was embracing the sharing economy.
“The sharing economy solves one of the biggest problems in our economy — under-utilised assets. Unlocking the value of these assets can have a transformative impact on productivity,” he said.
“The Opposition’s focus on the sharing economy reinforces the view that access to assets, not ownership, is the priority.
“The majority of companies operating in the sharing economy are Australian companies and pay their tax in Australia. We look forward to a level playing field that no longer favours multinationals with sophisticated tax shifting structures.
“What’s missing from the Opposition’s policy is how they will bring sharing economy principles to government owned assets. As a large owner of assets, government can unlock enormous savings and efficiencies.”
Start-up Airtasker’s co-founder and CEO Tim Fung said Airtasker was keen to hear how the Coalition replies to Labor’s principles.
“We haven’t yet heard the Liberal Party address the sharing economy - which is making headlines in Australia and is even a campaign issue in the US election,” he said.
“Beyond a policy framework, the next step for this trend is to accurately gauge sharing economy growth in Australia.”
Labor’s plan for the sharing economy
1. Rules and regulations must apply
2. Wages and working conditions must be at least equivalent to the prevailing industry standard
3. Everyone must pay their fair share of tax
4. Proper protection must exist through insurance and consumer law
5. Access for all including Australians with disabilities
6. Zero-tolerance for companies that flout the law
